profileText: A Representative from Massachusetts; born in Bangor, Maine (then a part of Massachusetts), September 9, 1777; attended Exeter and Byfield Academies; clerk on U.S.S. Crescent; appointed as secretary to the United States consul at Algiers and served two years; engaged in mercantile pursuits in Orrington, Maine (then Massachusetts); member of the State house of representatives 1806-1811; elected as a Federalist to the Fourteenth Congress (March 4, 1815-March 3, 1817); was drowned in the Ohio River August 24, 1818; memorial headstone placed in Mount Hope Cemetery, Bangor, Maine.

researchRecord.name: 1811-1816, 3 items.
researchRecord.description: Consisting of accounts of two voyages of James Carr documented in unbound volume, 14 Oct. [1811] - 9 Jan. [1812], and bound volume, 21 July 1815 - 4 May 1816, detailing operation of Carr's shipping business and giving his impressions of Charleston, S.C., Baltimore, Md., Liverpool, England, and elsewhere; Carr wrote these journals as a travel memoir for his wife to read upon his return. Carr's description of the earlier voyage, from Bangor, Maine, to Baltimore, Maryland, 14 Oct. [1811] - 9 Jan. [1812, was aboard the schooner Camden; his narrative includes observations of ports and sea life as well as many details on the operation of his business. The later voyage, Bangor, Me., to Charleston, S.C., and then to Liverpool, England, 21 July 1815 - 4 May 1816, was aboard the ship Mary. In this journal, Carr comments on South Carolinians and their agriculture, plantations, local customs, and slavery in the S.C. low country; Carr also includes the lyrics to several work songs used by African-American slave laborers who repaired Carr's boat in Charleston, S.C., as well as pen and ink sketches of icebergs encountered on the return voyage from Liverpool; Carr also records expenses incurred during his stay in Charleston and Liverpool. Also including letter, 24 June 1816, Bangor, Me., to Frank Carr, requesting that his brother apologize and settle a dispute with Mr. Emerson.
